page.title: 04C. of E. Parish Swyncombe
page.content: t. Botolphs church was built as a pil- rim church on the ridgeway for the succour of pilgrims travelling to Glastonbury. The monks built two dormitories now the site of two farm- houses. The dues were paid by the monks to Beck in Normandy until the 13th. century when the French were dispossed and the property passed to the Crown. The Lord Chancellor on behalf of the Queen and the Bishop of Oxford still appoint the incumbent. It has been a parish church since about 1730. The ecclesiastical parish covers Christmas Common, Swyncombe, Russells Water and Maidensgrove but excludes Pishill. The parish magazine goes to all 360 house- holds in the parish. Approximately 40 people are regular worshippers. No other religion has a place of worship in the area. Since 1833 St. Botolphs has been tractarian.
